addressleaf.section: Copie of a letter to my L. Treasurer June 10. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 10 June To my L Treasurer
It may please yo
r
L. I have heerw
th
sent a coppy of
e g
nall
states aunswear to
t
w
ch
I proposed in my
L Willughbyes
behalf. I am half of opinion
t
they will put me of w
th
shift
& delaies, &
fourme nothing in
e end of
t
w
ch
is required.
I do not doubt but yo
r
L. is adv
r
tized from
flushing
of
e
apprehending of
Adrian Vasseur
S
r
William Russells
secretary & what hath passed upon yt betwene
e garrison & those
of
Middlebrough.
The matt
r
hath bin fully debated here in
a full assembly of
e
g
nall
states
&
e
Counsell of state
together, wh
r
in yt hath bin resolved
t
seing he was taken
out of
e lib
r
tyes of flushing, & is a naturall borne
subject of
is countrey he ought to be proceeded against here
nev
r
eles to avoyd all suspition of
tiality yt was agreed
t
he should be removed fr
o
e
States of Zeland
to
e
Counsell of State & should be alwaies examined in my p
nc
e, or
in
e presence of some oth
r
minister of hir
Ma
ty
wh
r
upon
ey
requested me to write to
e Lieuten
t
governo
r
of flushing that
the Cap
nes
there would surcease fr
o
using any violence or
threatening the Inhabitant
of Middlborough. For myne owne
te
I cannot
ceave
t
any clause of
e contract doth [favor]
e
garrison [yet] there clayme for [decideng ]
e cause, In w
ch
respect
as likewyse for
t
I
[.]
sawe
a greate discontentment toward
yf they should be resisted in
is place in a matter of Justice,
& becaus I cannot conjecture how
e Capt
nes
can stand upon
theyr challenge in equity I have Joyned w
th
e State heer
& written to
M
r
Borlas
, &
M
r
Errington
t
they would accept
of such order as
e States would set downe. I cannot
omyt to acquaint yo
r
L. w
th
a necessary point of
is
consulta
o
n offered in a speech delivered by
Barnevelt
in
e behalf of
e g
nall
states, wh
r
in
e Counsell of State was
required to write a l
re
unto her Ma
ty
precisely signifyeng
t
unles her highnes would take order for
e bett
r
governing of her
people in
es countreyes, they should be foreced to publish to
e
world the whole course of all o
r
actions from
e beginning, so
as all men shall see in what sort we have
roceeded in these
countreyes, w
ch
for speciall respect
they have heth
r
to thought good
fol.279v
to keep secret. This kynde of speech was utt
r
ly condemned
by
e counsell of State, who thought yt suffycient to wryte
to
e LL. of hir Ma
tyes
Counsell, & to wryte w
th
more good
manner & regard of theyr dewty as will appere by theyr
l
re
already sent. Of such indignyties [offred] if I
would signify as often as occasyons ar ministred I should
comb
r
yo
r
L. w
th
many unpleasant l
re
s & advertisment
.
And besydes yf hir Ma
ty
would serve to take notice of
them, & require
e reparation of hir honor, I see
t
the
humor here of some would wax more
vers & obstinate
upon yt & not yeeld in
e end to any honorable satisfaction
In my voyadge homeward from
Berghen
I came by
Dordrecht
where I dealt w
th
e magistrates about
e
release of
S
r
John Wingfield
childe,
wh
r
in I found many
difficultyes, especially for
t
S
r
John Wingfield had
passed a graunt und
r
his hand (w
ch
they shewed me) that
they should have
e custody of
e childe till
e debt were
answeryd, besydes oth
r
allegations wherew
th
yt is needles
to troble yo
r
L. But in
e end I obtayned so much that 12
Dayes after my de
arture
e child was set at lib
r
ty by
publick sentence. The Ennemy is thought to bend his
forces agaynst
Blienbeck
&
Hoesen
[albeyt a] store of rayne
w
ch
hath bin heer of late hath caused him to retire from
Housden. The Towne hath had a new supply of men
& victuales so as yt is furnished w
th
1000 souldiors at
e
least & w
th
victualls for all
is summer, some outrages have
bin comitted among those w
th
in
e Towne w
ch
I think ar appeased.
Much cattell hath bin caried away by
e ennemy out of
Bommels wieert
, & 100 men w
ch
were sent by
Coronell Baufore
out of Bommell to skirmish w
th
em were slayne. At
Blienbyck ther ys nothing yet don by
S
r
Martyn Schencke
for
t
e
Count of Newenar
&
e
co unt of Oversteyn
by whose
forces he was to be assisted have heth
r
to detracted
e tyme
& lost great opportunityes, & all upon pryvat displeasure
& a littell [emulation], Ther ar sertayn gentlemen of
fol.280r
Frieese
t
have raysed of late upon theyr owne charg
1600 footemen for some secret exployt und
r
e conduct of
one
Clamet
who hath
mysed
e States to Joyne himself
fyrst w
th
S
r
Martin Schenck for
e succo
r
of Blienbeck
where
e nomb
r
of o
r
men alredy ar 2000 foote & 700 horse
but
e ennemy is farr stronger & not to be beaten but by
some stratageme, w
ch
Schenck hath undertaken. Yt is told
me for certayn by
Count Maurice
t
Parma
sendeth out
of Artoys 3000 footemen & 800 horse to
e ayd of
e
Leaguers.
